panels.description:
Total CPU utilization (all cores). 100% here means there is no CPU idle time at all. You can get per core usage at the CPUs section and per application usage at the Applications Monitoring section.

Keep an eye on iowait. If it is constantly high, your disks are a bottleneck and they slow your system down.

An important metric worth monitoring, is softirq. A constantly high percentage of softirq may indicate network driver issues.
panels.title: Total CPU utilization - $host

panels.description: Pressure Stall Information identifies and quantifies the disruptions caused by resource contentions. The "some" line indicates the share of time in which at least some tasks are stalled on CPU. The ratios (in %) are tracked as recent trends over 10-, 60-, and 300-second windows.
panels.title: Pressure - $host

panels.description: Current system load, i.e. the number of processes using CPU or waiting for system resources (usually CPU and disk). The 3 metrics refer to 1, 5 and 15 minute averages. The system calculates this once every 5 seconds.
panels.title: System Load Average - $host

panels.description: Total Disk I/O, for all physical disks. You can get detailed information about each disk at the Disks section and per application Disk usage at the Applications Monitoring section. Physical are all the disks that are listed in /sys/block, but do not exist in /sys/devices/virtual/block.
panels.title: Disk I/O - $host

panels.description: Memory paged from/to disk. This is usually the total disk I/O of the system.
panels.title: Memory Paged from/to disk - $host

panels.description: Total Disk I/O, for all physical disks. You can get detailed information about each disk at the Disks section and per application Disk usage at the Applications Monitoring section. Physical are all the disks that are listed in /sys/block, but do not exist in /sys/devices/virtual/block.
panels.title: Disk I/O - $host

panels.description: Memory paged from/to disk. This is usually the total disk I/O of the system.
panels.title: Memory Paged from/to disk - $host

panels.description: Pressure Stall Information identifies and quantifies the disruptions caused by resource contentions. The "some" line indicates the share of time in which at least some tasks are stalled on I/O. The "full" line indicates the share of time in which all non-idle tasks are stalled on I/O simultaneously. In this state actual CPU cycles are going to waste, and a workload that spends extended time in this state is considered to be thrashing. The ratios (in %) are tracked as recent trends over 10-, 60-, and 300-second windows.

links.title: More information about Pressure Stall Information

panels.title: I/O Pressure - $host

panels.description: Pressure Stall Information identifies and quantifies the disruptions caused by resource contentions. The "some" line indicates the share of time in which at least some tasks are stalled on I/O. The "full" line indicates the share of time in which all non-idle tasks are stalled on I/O simultaneously. In this state actual CPU cycles are going to waste, and a workload that spends extended time in this state is considered to be thrashing. The ratios (in %) are tracked as recent trends over 10-, 60-, and 300-second windows.

The "some" line indicates the share of time in which at least some tasks are stalled on I/O. The "full" line indicates the share of time in which all non-idle tasks are stalled on I/O simultaneously. panels.title: I/O Full Pressure - $host

panels.description: System Random Access Memory (i.e. physical memory) usage.
panels.title: System RAM - $host

panels.description: Pressure Stall Information identifies and quantifies the disruptions caused by resource contentions. The "some" line indicates the share of time in which at least some tasks are stalled on memory. The "full" line indicates the share of time in which all non-idle tasks are stalled on memory simultaneously. In this state actual CPU cycles are going to waste, and a workload that spends extended time in this state is considered to be thrashing. The ratios (in %) are tracked as recent trends over 10-, 60-, and 300-second windows.

links.title: More information about Pressure Stall Information

panels.title: Memory Pressure - $host

panels.description: Pressure Stall Information identifies and quantifies the disruptions caused by resource contentions. The "some" line indicates the share of time in which at least some tasks are stalled on memory. The "full" line indicates the share of time in which all non-idle tasks are stalled on memory simultaneously. In this state actual CPU cycles are going to waste, and a workload that spends extended time in this state is considered to be thrashing. The ratios (in %) are tracked as recent trends over 10-, 60-, and 300-second windows.

links.title: More information about Pressure Stall Information

panels.title: Memory Full Pressure - $host

panels.description: System swap memory usage. Swap space is used when the amount of physical memory (RAM) is full. When the system needs more memory resources and the RAM is full, inactive pages in memory are moved to the swap space (usually a disk, a disk partition or a file).

targets.query: SELECT mean("value") FROM "netdata.system.swap.free" WHERE ("host" =~ /^$host$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval) fill(null)

panels.title: System Swap - $host

panels.description: Total Swap I/O.
panels.title: Swap I/O - $host

panels.description: Total bandwidth of all physical network interfaces. This does not include lo, VPNs, network bridges, IFB devices, bond interfaces, etc. Only the bandwidth of physical network interfaces is aggregated. Physical are all the network interfaces that are listed in /proc/net/dev, but do not exist in /sys/devices/virtual/net.
panels.title: Physical Network Interfaces Aggregated Bandwidth - $host

panels.description: Total IPv4 Traffic.
panels.title: IPv4 Bandwidth - $host

panels.description: Total IPv6 Traffic.
panels.title: IPv6 Bandwidth - $host

panels.description: System processes. Running are the processes in the CPU. Blocked are processes that are willing to enter the CPU, but they cannot, e.g. because they wait for disk activity.
panels.title: System Processes - $host

panels.description: Number of new processes created.
panels.title: Started Processes - $host

panels.description: All system processes
panels.title: System Active Processes - $host

panels.description: Context Switches, is the switching of the CPU from one process, task or thread to another. If there are many processes or threads willing to execute and very few CPU cores available to handle them, the system is making more context switching to balance the CPU resources among them. The whole process is computationally intensive. The more the context switches, the slower the system gets.
panels.title: CPU Context Switches - $host

panels.description: Idle jitter is calculated by netdata. A thread is spawned that requests to sleep for a few microseconds. When the system wakes it up, it measures how many microseconds have passed. The difference between the requested and the actual duration of the sleep, is the idle jitter. This number is useful in real-time environments, where CPU jitter can affect the quality of the service (like VoIP media gateways).
panels.title: CPU Idle Jitter - $host

panels.description: Total number of CPU interrupts. Check system.interrupts that gives more detail about each interrupt and also the CPUs section where interrupts are analyzed per CPU core.
panels.title: CPU Interrupts - $host

panels.description: CPU interrupts in detail. At the CPUs section, interrupts are analyzed per CPU core.

targets.query: SELECT mean("value") FROM /netdata.system.interrupts.*/ WHERE ("host" =~ /^$host$/) AND $timeFilter GROUP BY time($__interval) fill(null)

panels.title: System interrupts - $host

panels.description: CPU softirqs in detail. At the CPUs section, softirqs are analyzed per CPU core.
panels.title: System softirqs - $host

panels.description: Statistics for CPUs SoftIRQs related to network receive work. Break down per CPU core can be found at CPU / softnet statistics. processed states the number of packets processed, dropped is the number packets dropped because the network device backlog was full (to fix them on Linux use sysctl to increase net.core.netdev_max_backlog), squeezed is the number of packets dropped because the network device budget ran out (to fix them on Linux use sysctl to increase net.core.netdev_budget and/or net.core.netdev_budget_usecs).

links.title: More information about identifying and troubleshooting network driver related issues can be found at Red Hat Enterprise Linux Network Performance Tuning Guide.

panels.title: System softnet_stat - $host

panels.description: Entropy, is a pool of random numbers (/dev/random) that is mainly used in cryptography. If the pool of entropy gets empty, processes requiring random numbers may run a lot slower (it depends on the interface each program uses), waiting for the pool to be replenished. Ideally a system with high entropy demands should have a hardware device for that purpose (TPM is one such device). There are also several software-only options you may install, like haveged, although these are generally useful only in servers.
panels.title: Available entropy - $host
IPC Shared Memory Number of Segments - $host

list.label: Host
list.name: host
list.query: SHOW TAG VALUES FROM "netdata.system.cpu.system" WITH KEY = "host"
